overall_summary: The reasoning demonstrates a practical approach to time-series forecasting with limited data, focusing on identifying daily seasonality and selecting a simple yet effective averaging method. The analyst systematically evaluates multiple techniques (SARIMA, ETS, seasonal decomposition) but ultimately chooses hourly averaging due to data constraints, ensuring computational efficiency while acknowledging its limitations for capturing emerging trends.
common_data_patterns: Complete data with no missing values
Variation in peak magnitudes across days (e.g., higher evening peaks)
key_insights: Limited data (96 points) necessitates simple methods to avoid overfitting
Hourly averaging effectively captures daily seasonality with minimal computation
Recent observations may be more representative but are balanced via averaging
Rounding precision (3 decimals) maintains consistency with input data
Explicit pattern repetition for multi-day forecasts ensures consistency
complexity_analysis: Moderately complex: Involves method evaluation, data pattern analysis, and step-by-step computations, but prioritizes implementable solutions over statistical sophistication due to data limitations.
